s.text: The rest of the industry is waiting to see how much control the government demands over recovered keys.

Since 1993, the administration has been using export restrictions as leverage to encourage American companies to adopt a standard with a "backdoor "--a route of entry for an outsider, such as the U.S. government, to recover encrypted data.

Vice President Gore offered an executive order that would ease export restrictions by 1) raising the export limit from 40 bits to 56 bits for at least the next two years (allowing U.S. companies to meet the current minimum commercial standard); 2) transferring export-license authority from a State Department military office, which almost always refuses applications, to the more friendly Commerce Department; 3) permitting export of encryption of unlimited strength, provided the technology incorporates "key recovery ." This is similar to key escrow, except there is no single key and the government holds nothing.
The Clinton administration's cryptography stand reflects the strong law-and-order views of the FBI and Justice Department.
A key that is 40 bits long, for example, has two raised to the 40 th power (2 40 ) possible combinations.
The strength of a computer encryption algorithm depends largely on "key length," essentially the number of possible combinations in the code.
